This study evaluated the catalytic efficiency of Au(I), Ag(I), and Cu(I) complexes in the azide‒alkyne cycloaddition (AAC) reaction through density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Cu(I) complexes exhibit superior catalytic performance, with lower energy barriers (8.8 kcal/mol) and a favorable Gibbs free energy of -0.9 kcal/mol in the key cycloaddition step, significantly outperforming Ag and Au complexes. Structural analysis revealed that shorter M−C bond lengths in the Cu complex contributed to increased stability. Additionally, the copper complex has a more negative Gibbs free energy for the formed metallacycle, indicating a thermodynamically favorable reaction pathway. Noncovalent interaction (NCI) and reduced density gradient (RDG) analyses of the Cu, Ag, and Au systems highlighted distinct interaction patterns influencing the reactivity. Furthermore, electron localization function (ELF) and localized orbital locator (LOL) analyses revealed bonding characteristics in those complexes. This study offers valuable insights into the mechanistic differences among Au(I), Ag(I), and Cu(I) complexes, paving the way for future research on enhancing the catalytic activity of copper, silver and gold complexes through ligand modification. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Density functional theory (DFT) CuAAC AgAAC AuAAC Triazoles NHC ligands Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction Copper-catalyzed azide‒alkyne cycloaddition (CuAAC) reactions constitute a cornerstone of "click chemistry," a powerful synthetic strategy used to create 1,2,3-substituted triazoles from azides and terminal alkynes [1–13]. Unlike uncatalyzed Huisgen cycloaddition, which requires high temperatures and yields a mixture of 1,4- and 1,5-triazole isomers, CuAAC occurs under mild conditions, producing a 1,4-regioisomer with high selectivity [14–19]. This specificity and mild reaction environment make CuAAC a valuable tool in various fields, including organic synthesis, nanotechnology, chemical biology, medicinal chemistry, drug discovery, and materials science [20–26]. N-heterocyclic carbenes (NHCs) have become increasingly important in organometallic chemistry, particularly in CuAAC reactions, owing to their strong σ-donating ability and the stability they impart to metal complexes [27–31]. NHCs are known for their ability to form robust bonds with metals, which enhances the stability of the resulting complexes and can significantly influence the reactivity and selectivity of catalytic processes. In the study by González-Lainez et al. (2022) [32], new polynuclear catalysts based on N-heterocyclic carbenes (NHCs) were developed and applied to CuAAC reactions. These catalysts, such as [Cu2(μ-Br)2(tBuImCH2pyCH2NEt2)]2, offer enhanced stability to reactive copper species, which are typically prone to disproportionation and degradation. This study utilized density functional theory (DFT) to investigate the catalytic mechanism, revealing that the NHC ligands not only stabilize the active copper centers but also play a crucial role in the activation of the alkyne substrate. To explore the potential for the substitution of copper with other metals, such as silver and gold, the initial aim was to assess whether these metals could exhibit unique reactivity or catalytic properties [3,33–39]. However, our computational analysis indicated that compared with copper, silver and gold do not enhance the activity or alter the reaction mechanism. Silver, despite its similar ionic radius and electronic configuration, did not demonstrate improved catalytic efficiency. Similarly, although gold is known for its ability to activate alkynes through π-coordination, which can increase the electrophilicity of alkynes and facilitate nucleophilic attack by azides, our analysis did not reveal any new reaction pathways or increased efficiency compared with copper. Therefore, while these metals offer interesting theoretical possibilities, our results underscore the effectiveness of copper within the [Cu2(μ-Br)2(tBuImCH2pyCH2NEt2)]2 complex for CuAAC reactions, confirming its stability and catalytic properties in this reaction pathway. Using computational methods such as DFT, we can understand the electronic structure of active sites, transition states, and energy profiles of reaction pathways, helping to determine how different metals affect the kinetics and thermodynamics of the reaction, as well as the stability and reactivity of catalysts. This research can offer valuable guidelines for designing new catalysts that leverage the unique properties of different metals by modifying the properties of NHC ligands or the coordination environment of metal centers to increase the reactivity or selectivity for specific substrates. Studying AgAAC and AuAAC catalysts contributes to the development of catalytic systems for other reactions in organic synthesis and materials science, thereby enhancing catalytic performance. We performed NCI (Noncovalent Interactions), RDG (Reduced Density Gradient) [40–43], ELF (Electron Localization Function) [44], and LOL (Localized Orbital Locator) [45] analyses on silver and gold catalysts to gain deeper insights into their electronic structures and interactions. NCI and RDG analyses are tools used to visualize and quantify weak noncovalent interactions, such as van der Waals forces and hydrogen bonds, within catalytic systems, revealing differences in interaction strength and nature between the two metals. ELF and LOL, on the other hand, are used to provide detailed visualizations of electron localization and orbital interactions, offering insights into electron pairing and bonding characteristics. Together, these analyses provide a comprehensive understanding of the catalytic behavior and stability of the two systems. Computational details The MN12-L/Def2-SVP basis set was selected for all the elements [46,47], whereas the Def2-TZVP basis sets, which incorporate pseudopotentials for Ag and Au, were employed for the transition metals (M) [48]. This approach was chosen for its computational accuracy, ability to meet convergence criteria, success in obtaining RC structures in our previous studies [2,3,6,7,11,12], and alignment with experimental data. Calculations were performed via Gaussian 16 RevC.01 [49], with the "integral=grid=ultrafine" setting to ensure high precision. These calculations were supplemented with single-point calculations via the conductor-like polarizable continuum model (CPCM) at the same theoretical level [50], which uses acetonitrile to simulate real conditions and study the MAAC reaction mechanisms. Vibrational frequency analyses confirmed the presence of one imaginary frequency in the transition states. The electronic energies (E o ), G corr , and optimized geometries of the catalytic cycle components were obtained via the MN12-L method in the gas phase. NCI, RDG, ELF, and LOL analyses were conducted via Multiwfn 3.8 software [51], and the colored plots were visualized via visual molecular dynamics (VMD). Results and discussions Sharpless and colleagues first explored the CuAAC mechanism in 2002 [17], with further insights provided by theoretical and experimental studies. Fokin's DFT studies suggested that a second copper atom enhances reaction Scheme 1 [19], a finding that was later supported by experiments. The proposed mechanism, which was later refined, highlights the importance of azide coordination with the copper atom bound to the alkynyl group. This study presents novel Ag(I) and Au(I) coordination polymers with tridentate NHC-py-L ligands. This work examines their application in base-free AAC reactions and conducts DFT studies to better understand the reaction mechanism. The Gibbs free energy (ΔG298 ) landscape for the CuAAC reaction catalyzed by A and the selected transition state structures are detailed in Scheme 2 and Fig. 1 . Initially, the alkyne undergoes π-coordination to the M1−M2 center, forming intermediate B. This step results in energy increases of 2.3 (Cu), 8.1 (Ag), and 12.2 (Au) kcal/mol. This coordination decreases the M1−M2 distance from 2.629 (Cu), 2.929 (Ag), and 3.127 (Au) Å to 2.561 (Cu), 2.791 (Ag), and 2.763 (Au) Å. This initial interaction highlights the relatively more significant stabilizing effect in the copper complex. The more significant energy increase in the gold complex indicates that, compared with copper and silver, gold is less efficient at stabilizing alkyne coordination. The NHC moiety subsequently facilitates the deprotonation of the alkyne via TSB-C , producing zwitterionic intermediate C. This step results in effective energy barriers of 25.2 (Cu), 27.6 (Ag), and 33.2 (Au) kcal/mol under reaction conditions in neat phenylacetylene, and the M1−M2 distances of TSB-C are 2.496 (Cu), 2.835 (Ag), and 3.047 (Au) Å (Fig. 1). Intermediate C, which corresponds to a σ,π-bis(metal)acetylide complex, is more stable than intermediate A by -9.7 (Cu), -7.8 (Ag), and -5.8 (Au) kcal/mol. This stabilization is consistent with experimental observations [32], such as the formation of [(CuBr)2(CCPh)(tBuHImCH2pyCH2NEt2)] upon the reaction of A with phenylacetylene. The lower energy barriers and greater stability of the copper complex suggest that copper is more effective at promoting this step than silver and gold are. In the following step, the azide coordinates to the metal center associated with the alkynyl moiety, forming intermediate D. The ΔG298 values for this intermediate are -5.9 (Cu), -3.4 (Ag), and -0.9 (Au) kcal/mol. This coordination causes the mode of the alkynyl ligand to change to μ2-η1, reducing the M1−M2 distance from 2.994 (Cu), 3.035 (Ag), and 3.478 (Au) Å in C to 2.479 (Cu), 2.943 (Ag), and 3.412 (Au) Å in D. A more significant reduction in the M1−M2 distance in the copper complex indicates stronger metal‒metal interactions, contributing to the overall stability of the intermediate. The cycloaddition step between the azide and alkyne, mediated by the metal active center, results in the formation of six-membered metallacycle E. This step occurs via TSD-E , dictating the regioselectivity of the process and the formation of the 1,4-disubstituted 1,2,3-triazole product. The activation energy ( E # ) barriers for this step are 8.8 (Cu), 20.6 (Ag), and 24.3 (Au) kcal/mol, indicating the superiority of copper in facilitating this transformation (Scheme 2). During this step, both metal atoms actively participate, as evidenced by the M1−C distances of 1.909 (Cu), 2.042 (Ag), and 1.998 (Au) Å and M2−C distances of 1.924 (Cu), 2.091 (Ag), and 2.040 (Au) Å, along with M1−M2 distances of 2.445 (Cu), 2.687 (Ag), and 2.770 (Au) Å (Fig. 2 ). The ΔG298 values for TSD-E are -0.9 (Cu), 12.7 (Ag), and 18.5 (Au) kcal/mol. These values are notably lower for copper, demonstrating its efficiency in the cycloaddition step. When the binuclear pathway for TS1Bi with different ligands was compared (Fig. 3 ), for copper, the ΔG298 values for L1, L2, L5, L6, L7, L8 and L9 [2,6,11,12] were 8.5 kcal/mol, 2.3 kcal/mol (L2), 7.6 kcal/mol (L5), 9.9 kcal/mol (L6), 8.8 kcal/mol (L7), 9.3 kcal/mol (L8), and 16.8 kcal/mol (L9), respectively. The TSD-E energy for copper (-0.9 kcal/mol) is lower than that of these TS1Bi barriers, highlighting the efficiency of the TSD-E transition state in the copper-mediated reaction. For silver, the ΔG298 values for L1, L2, L3, L4, L9, L10, and L11 [3,11,12] were 18.8 (L1), 11.9 (L2), 9.8 (L3), 14.6 (L4), 22.8 (L9), 28.4 (L10), and 18.7 (L11) kcal/mol, respectively. These values are greater than the TSD-E energy (12.7 kcal/mol), indicating that the transition state for TS1Bi is more challenging for silver complexes, particularly those with L10. For gold, the ΔG298 for L1 [11] in the binuclear pathway is 20.7 kcal/mol, which is higher than the TSD-E energy of 18.5 kcal/mol. This suggests that while gold is less efficient overall, the energy barrier for the TS1Bi binuclear pathway is somewhat closer to that of TSD-E , reflecting a comparably higher energy landscape. The resulting metallacycle E has ΔG298 values of -19.6 (Cu), -1.9 (Ag), and -4.4 (Au) kcal/mol. The lower energy barrier and greater stability of the copper complex in TSD-E and TS1Bi indicate that copper is more efficient in this step than silver and gold are. The final contraction of the six-membered metallacycle E, which forms the second C−N bond and yields the triazolyl species F, proceeds via TSE-F (Fig. 2 and Scheme 2). The energy barriers for this step are 1.9 (Cu), 5 (Ag), and 5.5 (Au) kcal/mol. This step is highly exergonic, with F being 32.7 (Cu), 55.2 (Ag), and 46.4 (Au) kcal/mol more stable than E is, corresponding to relative ΔG298 values of -52.3 (Cu), -57.1 (Ag), and -50.9 (Au) kcal/mol, respectively. The M1−M2 distances in F, indicative of strong metallophilic interactions, are 2.452 (Cu), 2.732 (Ag), and 2.708 Å (Au). The triazolyl moiety bridges both metal atoms with M1−C distances of 1.914 Å (Cu), 2.081 Å (Ag), and 2.107 (Au) Å and M2−C distances of 2.137 (Cu), 2.302 (Ag), and 2.040 (Au) Å (Fig. 4 ). The significant stabilization and shorter M1−M2 distances in the copper complex again suggest that copper is more effective in stabilizing the final product. The comparative analysis of the ΔG298 profiles and bond lengths across the copper-, silver-, and gold-catalyzed reactions indicates that copper is the most efficient catalyst for the CuAAC reaction. Copper complexes consistently exhibit lower energy barriers and greater stability throughout the reaction steps. The shorter M1−M2 distances in the copper complexes also highlight stronger metal‒metal interactions, which contribute to the overall stability and efficiency of the catalytic process. This insight underscores the potential of copper in CuAAC applications and provides valuable guidelines for designing effective silver and gold catalysts for similar reactions. The unique electronic properties and coordination environments of different metals can be further exploited to enhance their catalytic performance in various organic synthesis and material science applications. NCI and RDG analysis Based on the NCI (noncovalent interaction) and RDG (reduced density gradient) plots for catalysts A with (Ag) and (Au), we can observe distinct noncovalent interaction patterns and interaction intensities associated with each metal center (Fig. 5 ). The NCI plots illustrate the noncovalent interaction regions in the molecular structure, with the green regions indicating weak van der Waals interactions, the blue regions representing attractive interactions, and the red regions showing repulsive interactions. In the copper complex, strong attractive interactions between the copper and surrounding ligands are visible, suggesting relatively stable bonding facilitated by balanced attractive and repulsive forces. In contrast, the interaction patterns of the gold and silver complexes differ. The silver complex has a reduced intensity in attractive interactions, as indicated by the blue–green regions in the NCI plot. This change may imply a weaker or more diffuse interaction with ligands, possibly leading to lower stability or catalytic efficiency than those of copper. The gold complex displays unique interaction features with slightly higher repulsive forces, as shown by the distinct red regions, possibly resulting from the larger atomic radius and different electronic properties of gold. These factors could contribute to a less efficient catalytic process, as observed in the RDG analysis, which further confirms the qualitative differences in the electronic environments and noncovalent interactions around each metal center. The RDG scatter plots further support these observations by illustrating the variation in the reduced density gradients for each catalyst. The copper complex shows a balanced profile with significant interaction density, whereas the silver and gold complexes show lower overall densities, indicating less effective stabilization through noncovalent interactions. This difference may contribute to the observed catalytic behavior, where copper demonstrates superior activity due to the optimized balance of interaction forces, whereas silver and gold show relatively lower activities and stability due to their altered noncovalent interaction profiles. ELF and LOL analysis The electron localization function (ELF) and localized orbital locator (LOL) plots are valuable for assessing the electronic characteristics and bonding interactions within complexes of copper (Cu), silver (Ag), and gold (Au) with bromine atoms and the surrounding ligands (Fig. 6 ). These visualizations help reveal how electron localization and bonding strength vary with each metal, which can significantly impact their catalytic properties. In the ELF plots, shown in light blue, areas with high electron localization highlight regions where electron pairs are strongly concentrated, indicating covalent-like interactions. The copper complex exhibited dense ELF regions around both the copper and bromine atoms, suggesting that the electron density was well distributed across the bonds. This high degree of electron localization around copper indicates stronger, more stable covalent interactions than the other metals do. Silver, on the other hand, shows slightly less electron density around its metal center, indicating somewhat weaker interactions with bromine, although it still has some covalent character. Gold displays the least electron localization in the ELF plots, suggesting weaker bonding interactions with bromine and potentially more polarized or ionic character in its bonds. This trend suggests that copper complexes may be more robust and less prone to degradation under catalytic conditions because of these stronger interactions. The LOL plots, illustrated in light red, offer additional insights into the spatial localization of orbitals and orbital stability. Copper again shows higher orbital localization, indicating that the orbitals around copper are well confined and stable, which could support greater reactivity and selectivity in catalytic processes. The LOL regions around silver are slightly more diffuse, which is consistent with weaker orbital interactions than those of copper, while still forming relatively stable bonds. Gold, however, shows much more dispersed LOL regions, reflecting a lower degree of orbital localization, which could imply a greater likelihood of bond rearrangements or weaker retention of its surrounding ligands. However, silver and gold may have niche applications where their specific electronic properties are advantageous, albeit potentially less stable than those of copper. Conclusion This study provides a comprehensive DFT analysis of the cycloaddition reactions mediated by Au(I) and Ag(I) complexes, emphasizing the differences in their catalytic efficiencies compared with that of Cu(I). The results demonstrate that copper has a significantly lower energy barrier and greater thermodynamic stability in forming the key metallacycle, reaffirming its position as the most effective catalyst among the three. The higher energy barriers associated with silver and gold indicate that although they are viable catalysts, their practical utility is limited relative to that of copper. Additionally, noncovalent interaction (NCI) and reduced density gradient (RDG) analyses for the Ag and Au systems reveal specific interaction patterns that influence the stability and reactivity of these complexes, whereas electron localization function (ELF) and localized orbital locator (LOL) analyses illustrate differences in electron distribution that further impact bonding characteristics. These insights contribute to a deeper understanding of the mechanistic pathways of metal-catalyzed cycloadditions and underscore the superior performance of copper in synthetic applications. Future studies may focus on modifying ligands to improve the catalytic activity of copper, silver and gold complexes, potentially broadening their use in organic synthesis. coredata.dc:description: This study evaluated the catalytic efficiency of Au(I), Ag(I), and Cu(I) complexes in the azide‒alkyne cycloaddition (AAC) reaction through density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Cu(I) complexes exhibit superior catalytic performance, with lower energy barriers (8.8 kcal/mol) and a favorable Gibbs free energy of -0.9 kcal/mol in the key cycloaddition step, significantly outperforming Ag and Au complexes. Structural analysis revealed that shorter M−C bond lengths in the Cu complex contributed to increased stability. Additionally, the copper complex has a more negative Gibbs free energy for the formed metallacycle, indicating a thermodynamically favorable reaction pathway. Noncovalent interaction (NCI) and reduced density gradient (RDG) analyses of the Cu, Ag, and Au systems highlighted distinct interaction patterns influencing the reactivity. Furthermore, electron localization function (ELF) and localized orbital locator (LOL) analyses revealed bonding characteristics in those complexes. This study offers valuable insights into the mechanistic differences among Au(I), Ag(I), and Cu(I) complexes, paving the way for future research on enhancing the catalytic activity of copper, silver and gold complexes through ligand modification.
